{{lead too short|date=October 2011}} {{linkrot|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox OS | name = Chromium OS | logo = [[File:Chromium 11 Wordmark Logo.svg|200px|center|Chromium]] | screenshot = | caption = Screenshot of Chromium OS Vanilla v0.13 running in a [[Virtual Machine]] | developer = [[Google|Google Inc.]] | family = [[Unix-like]] | license = Various | language = | kernel_type = [[Monolithic kernel|Monolithic]] ([[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]]{{cite web|url=http://www.chromium.org/chromium-os/chromiumos-design-docs/chromium-os-kernel|title=Kernel Design: Background, Upgrades|publisher=Google|accessdate=7 September 2011}} [[Linux kernel]]) | ui = [[Graphical user interface|Graphical]] (Web-based) | working_state = [[Alpha release|Alpha]] | website = [http://dev.chromium.org/chromium-os dev.chromium.org] | supported_platforms = [[x86]], [[ARM architecture|ARM]]{{cite web|last=Womack|first=Brian|date=2009-07-08|accessdate=2009-07-08|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aTd2k.YdQZ.Y|title=Google to Challenge Microsoft With Operating System|publisher=Bloomberg.com}} | updatemodel = | package_manager = [[Portage (software)|Portage]]{{cite web|url=http://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/group/chromium-os-dev/browse_thread/thread/337cca9a0da59ad6/9354a38894da5df5|title=Upcoming build system changes|last=Cairns|first=Ryan|date=2010-02-05|work=Chromium OS dev|publisher=Google Groups|accessdate=2010-03-23}} }} '''Chromium OS''' is the [[open source]] development version of [[Google Chrome OS]]. Chrome OS's [[source code]] was released on November 19, 2009 under the same [[BSD licenses|BSD license]] as Chromium OS.{{cite web|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2009/11/releasing-chromium-os-open-source.html|title=Releasing the Chromium OS open source project|last=Sengupta|first=Caesar|date=2009-11-19|work=Official Google Blog|publisher=Google, Inc.|accessdate=2009-11-19}} ==User interface== Chromium OS uses the new new:tab page found in Google Chrome to open web apps. Compared to prior builds, this replaces the applications page. Chromium OS provides a clock, battery indicator and network status indicator. The {{Keypress|Ctrl|Alt|/}} key combination toggles a keyboard overlay that shows the function of all the shortcut keys used in Chromium, including task and memory managers also found in the Chrome browser, and a command-line interface that accepts common Linux commands.{{cite web|url=http://www.chromium.org/chromium-os/how-tos-and-troubleshooting/developer-faq|title=Developer FAQ|publisher=Google|accessdate=12 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/software/operatingsystems/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=222000239|title=Google Chrome OS Previewed|last=Yegulalp |first=Serdar|date=December 5, 2009 |work=InformationWeek|accessdate=6 December 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Application-Development/REVIEW-Google-Chrome-OS-Developer-Edition-Provides-Intriguing-Look-at-WebOnly-Computing-446612/|title=REVIEW: Google Chrome OS Developer Edition Provides Intriguing Look at Web-Only Computing |last=Rapoza|first=Jim|date=December 3, 2009|publisher=eWeek.com|accessdate=4 December 2009}} ==Architecture== In preliminary design documents, Google describes a three-tier architecture: [[firmware]], [[web browser]] and [[window manager]], and system-level software and [[Userland (computing)|userland]] services.{{cite web|url=http://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/dev/chromium-os/chromiumos-design-docs/security-overview|title=Security Overview: Chromium OS design documents|publisher=Google|accessdate=25 November 2009}} * The firmware contributes to fast boot time by not probing for [[hardware]], such as [[floppy disk]] drives, that are no longer common on computers, especially [[netbook]]s. The firmware also contributes to security by verifying each step in the boot process and incorporating system recovery. * System-level software includes the Linux kernel that has been patched to improve boot performance. Userland software has been trimmed to essentials, with management by [[Upstart]], which can launch services in parallel, re-spawn crashed jobs, and defer services in the interest of faster booting. * The window manager handles user interaction with multiple client windows much like other [[X window]] managers. == Builds == By May 2010, compiled versions of the work-in-progress source code had been downloaded from the Internet more than a million times. The most popular version entitled "Chromium OS Flow" was created by Liam McLoughlin, a then 17-year-old college student in [[Manchester, England]], posting under the name "Hexxeh". McLoughlin's builds boot from a USB memory stick and included features that Google engineers had not yet implemented, such as support for the [[Java (programming language)|Java programming language]].{{cite news|last=Stone|first=Brad|title=Test Flights Into the Google Cloud|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/09/business/09ping.html?scp=1&sq=hexxeh&st=nyt|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 7, 2010}} While Google did not expect that hobbyists would use and evaluate Chromium OS ahead of its official release, [[Sundar Pichai]], Google vice president of product management, said that "what people like Hexxeh are doing is amazing to see." Pichai said the early releases were an unintended consequence of open source development. "If you decide to do open-source projects, you have to be open all the way." Hexxeh's work continued into the following year. He announced "Chromium OS Lime" in December 2010,{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=Now with a citrus twist|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117639|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}} and in January 2011, released "Luigi", an application designed to "[[Privilege escalation|jailbreak]]"/"[[Rooting (Android OS)|root]]" the [[Google]] [[Cr-48]] "Mario" prototype hardware and install a generic [[BIOS]].{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=Your princess is in another castleâ¦|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117655|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}} The developer made the builds available in virtual machine format on March 13, 2011, the date of his most recent blog posting.{{cite web|last=Hexxeh|title=In my VirtualBox?|url=http://hexxeh.net/?p=328117684|work=Hexxeh's Blog|accessdate=30 June 2011}} With no official build of Chromium OS forthcoming from Google, Hexxeh's "Vanilla" nightly builds of Chromium OS remain the principal resource for people wanting to try Chromium OS. In May 2011, [[Dell Computer]] also released a new build for Dell Inspiron Mini 10v netbook, following up on an earlier build released almost 18 months earlier. The build did not support audio, but was bootable from a USB drive.{{cite news|last=Linder|first=Brad|title=Dell releases Chromium OS build for Inspiron Mini netbooks|url=http://liliputing.com/2011/05/dell-releases-chromium-os-build-for-inspiron-mini-netbooks.html|accessdate=16 May 2011|newspaper=Liliputing|date=May 15, 2011}}
